{{IPAc-en|'|Z|i:}} {{respell|ZHEE}}; {{zh|s=习近平|p=Xí Jìnpíng}}, pronounced {{IPAc-cmn|x|i|2|-|j|in|4|.|p|ing|2}}}} (born 15 June 1953) is a Chinese politician who has been the [[general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party]] (CCP) and [[Chairman of the Central Military Commission (China)|chairman of the Central Military Commission]] (CMC), and thus the [[paramount leader]] of China, since 2012. Xi has been serving as the seventh [[president of China]] since 2013. As a member of the fifth [[Generations of Chinese leadership|generation of Chinese leadership]], Xi is the first CCP general secretary born after the [[Proclamation of the People's Republic of China|establishment of the People's Republic of China]] (PRC). {{Xi Jinping sidebar}} The son of Chinese communist veteran [[Xi Zhongxun]], Xi was exiled to rural [[Yanchuan County]] as a teenager following his father's purge during the [[Cultural Revolution]]. He lived in a [[yaodong]] in the village of Liangjiahe, [[Shaanxi|Shaanxi province]], where he joined the CCP after several failed attempts and worked as the local [[Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary|party secretary]]. After studying [[chemical engineering]] at [[Tsinghua University]] as a [[Worker-Peasant-Soldier student|worker-peasant-soldier student]], Xi rose through the ranks politically in China's coastal provinces. Xi was [[governor of Fujian]] from 1999 to 2002, before becoming governor and party secretary of neighboring [[Politics of Zhejiang|Zhejiang]] from 2002 to 2007. Following the dismissal of the party secretary of Shanghai, [[Chen Liangyu]], Xi was transferred to replace him for a brief period in 2007. He subsequently joined the [[Politburo Standing Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|Politburo Standing Committee]] (PSC) of the CCP the same year and was the first-ranking secretary of the [[Secretariat of the Chinese Communist Party|Central Secretariat]] in October 2007. In 2008, he was designated as [[Hu Jintao]]'s presumed [[Succession of power in China|successor]] as paramount leader. Towards this end, Xi was appointed [[Vice President of China|vice president of the PRC]] and [[Vice Chairman of the Central Military Commission|vice chairman of the CMC]]. He officially received the title of [[leadership core]] from the CCP in 2016. While overseeing China's domestic policy, Xi has introduced far-ranging measures to enforce party discipline and strengthen internal unity. His [[Anti-corruption campaign under Xi Jinping|anti-corruption campaign]] led to the downfall of prominent incumbent and retired CCP officials, including former PSC member [[Zhou Yongkang]]. For the sake of promoting "[[common prosperity]]", Xi has enacted a series of policies designed to increase equality, overseen [[Targeted Poverty Alleviation|targeted poverty alleviation]] programs, and directed a broad crackdown in 2021 against the tech and tutoring sectors. Furthermore, he has expanded support for [[State-owned enterprises of China|state-owned enterprises]] (SOEs), advanced [[military-civil fusion]], and attempted to reform China's property sector. Following the onset of [[COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China]], he initially presided over a [[zero-COVID]] policy from January 2020 to December 2022 before ultimately shifting towards a [[mitigation strategy]]. Xi has pursued a more aggressive foreign policy, particularly with regard to [[China–United States relations|China's relations with the U.S.]], the [[nine-dash line]] in the [[Territorial disputes in the South China Sea|South China Sea]], and the [[Sino-Indian border dispute]]. Additionally, for the sake of advancing Chinese economic interests abroad, Xi has sought to expand China's influence in Africa and Eurasia by championing the [[Belt and Road Initiative]]. Despite meeting with Taiwanese president [[Ma Ying-jeou]] in 2015, Xi presided over a deterioration in relations between Beijing and Taipei under Ma's successor, [[Tsai Ing-wen]]. In 2020, Xi oversaw the passage of a [[2020 Hong Kong national security law|national security law in Hong Kong]] which clamped down on political opposition in the city, especially [[Pro-democracy camp (Hong Kong)|pro-democracy activists]]. Since coming to power, Xi's tenure has witnessed a significant increase in [[Censorship in China|censorship]] and [[Mass surveillance in China|mass surveillance]], a deterioration in [[Human rights in China|human rights]], including the [[Persecution of Uyghurs in China|internment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang]], the rise of a [[Xi Jinping's cult of personality|cult of personality]] around his leadership, and the removal of term limits for the presidency in 2018. Xi's political ideas and principles, known as [[Xi Jinping Thought]], have been incorporated into the [[Constitution of the Chinese Communist Party|party]] and [[Constitution of China|national constitutions]]. As the central figure of the fifth generation of leadership of the PRC, Xi has centralized institutional power by taking on multiple positions, including new CCP committees on national security, economic and social reforms, military restructuring and modernization, and the internet. In October 2022, Xi secured a third term as CCP General Secretary, and was re-elected state president for a third term in March 2023. {{TOC limit|3}} ==Early life and education== Xi Jinping was born on 15 June 1953 in [[Beijing]],{{sfn|Wong|2023|p=21}} the third child of [[Xi Zhongxun]] and his second wife [[Qi Xin]]. After the [[Proclamation of the People's Republic of China|founding of the PRC]] in 1949, Xi's father held a series of posts, including the chief of the [[Publicity Department of the Chinese Communist Party]], [[Vice Premier of China|vice-premier]], and [[Vice Chairperson of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress|vice chairperson of the National People's Congress]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/china-profile-xi-jinping/24764283.html|title=Profile: Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping|date=7 November 2012|publisher=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Beijing No. 25 School,{{cite web |last1=Li |first1=Cheng |title=Xi Jinping's Inner Circle (Part 2: Friends from Xi's Formative Years) He became friends with [[Liu He (politician)|Liu He]], who attended [[Beijing 101 Middle School|Beijing No. 101 School]] in the same district, and who later became China's vice premier and a close advisor to Xi after he became China's paramount leader.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/dec/29/power-behind-the-thrones-10-movers-and-shakers-for-2020|title=The power behind the thrones: 10 political movers and shakers who will shape 2020|last=Tisdall|first=Simon|date=29 December 2019|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=16 January 2020|issn=0029-7712|author-link=Simon Tisdall|archive-date=5 November 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211105032127/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/dec/29/power-behind-the-thrones-10-movers-and-shakers-for-2020|url-status=live}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/blessed-by-xi-jinping-the-new-captain-of-chinas-economy-1519688592|title=Who Is 'Uncle He?' The Man in Charge of China's Economy|last=Wei|first=Lingling|date=27 February 2018|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|access-date=16 January 2020|archive-date=3 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211003102625/https://www.wsj.com/articles/blessed-by-xi-jinping-the-new-captain-of-chinas-economy-1519688592|url-status=live}} In 1963, when he was aged 10, his father was purged from the CCP and sent to work in a factory in [[Luoyang]], Henan.{{sfn|Bouée|2010|p=93}} In May 1966, the [[Cultural Revolution]] cut short Xi's secondary education when all secondary classes were halted for students to criticise and fight their teachers. Student militants ransacked the Xi family home and one of Xi's sisters, Xi Heping, "was persecuted to death."{{cite web |date=14 October 2013 |script-title=zh:习近平：＂我坚信我的父亲是一个大英雄＂ |trans-title=Xi Jinping: "I firmly believe my father is a great hero" |url=http://www.gapp.gov.cn/contents/2091/157500.shtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305150646/http://www.gapp.gov.cn/contents/2091/157500.shtml |archive-date=5 March 2018 |access-date=6 March 2018 |publisher=[[State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television]] |language=zh |script-quote=zh:女儿习和平……在＂文化大革命＂中被迫害致死，是习仲勋难以抹去的心痛。|trans-quote=His daughter Xi Heping... was persecuted to death during the "Cultural Revolution", which is a heartache that Xi Zhongxun could not erase.}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/25/world/asia/xi-jinping-china-cultural-revolution.html |title=Cultural Revolution Shaped Xi Jinping, From Schoolboy to Survivor |last1=Buckley|first1=Chris |last2=Tatlow|first2=Didi Kirsten|date=24 September 2015 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=6 March 2018|url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305150638/https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/25/world/asia/xi-jinping-china-cultural-revolution.html |archive-date=5 March 2018 |url-access=limited}} Later, his mother was forced to publicly denounce his father, as he was paraded before a crowd as an enemy of the revolution. His father was later imprisoned in 1968 when Xi was aged 15. In 1968, Xi submitted an application to the Bayi School's Reform Committee and insisted on leaving Beijing for the countryside.{{cite book |last=Shi |first=Z. C. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MKSRswEACAAJ |script-title=zh:习近平的七年知青岁月 |publisher=China Central Party School Press |year=2017 |isbn=978-7-5035-6163-4 |page={{pn|date=November 2024}} |language=zh |trans-title=Xi Jinping's Seven Years as an Educated Youth |access-date=2024-08-18}} On January 13, 1969, they left Beijing and arrived in Liangjiahe Village, [[Yan'an]], Shaanxi, alongside the Mao Zedong's [[Down to the Countryside Movement]].{{cite web |url=http://v.youku.com/v_show/id_XMzM2NTc1MjAwOA==.html |script-title=zh:不忘初心：是什么造就了今天的习主席?|date=30 January 2018|website=[[Youku]]|language=zh-Hans |trans-title=What Were His Original Intentions? The President Xi of Today |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180130204306/http://v.youku.com/v_show/id_XMzM2NTc1MjAwOA==.html |archive-date=30 January 2018 |access-date=30 January 2018}} The rural areas of Yan'an were very backward,{{Cite news|last=Page|first=Jeremy|date=23 December 2020|title=How the U.S. Misread China's Xi: Hoping for a Globalist, It Got an Autocrat|language=en-US|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/xi-jinping-globalist-autocrat-misread-11608735769|access-date=25 December 2020|issn=0099-9660|archive-date=24 December 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201224233237/https://www.wsj.com/articles/xi-jinping-globalist-autocrat-misread-11608735769|url-status=live}} which created a big gap for Xi as a teenager. He once recalled that he had to overcome "five hurdles" ([[flea]], food, life, labor and thought hurdle),{{cite news |date=2022-05-23 |script-title=zh:《足迹》第1集：过＂五关＂有多难 |trans-title="Footprints" Episode 1: How difficult is it to pass the "Five Gates" |url=http://www.news.cn/politics/leaders/2022-05/23/c_1128675005.htm |access-date=2024-08-18 |website=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |language=zh |archive-date=18 August 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240818143438/http://www.news.cn/politics/leaders/2022-05/23/c_1128675005.htm |url-status=live }} and the experience led him to feel affinity with the rural poor. After a few months, unable to stand rural life, he ran away to Beijing. He was arrested during a crackdown on deserters from the countryside and sent to a work camp to dig ditches, but he later returned to the village, under the persuasion of his aunt Qi Yun and uncle Wei Zhenwu.{{cite news |date=2018-07-01 |script-title=zh:习近平的七年知青岁月 |trans-title=Xi Jinping's Seven Years as an Educated Youth |url=https://www.chinanews.com.cn/m/gn/2018/07-01/8552619.shtml Secretary|party secretary]] of Liangjiahe, where he lived in a [[yaodong|cave house]].{{Cite news |last=Lim |first=Louisa |date=9 November 2012 |title=For China's Rising Leader, A Cave Was Once Home |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210226054335/https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/19/asia/china-xi-jinping-village-intl/index.html |url-status=live}} In 1973, Yanchuan County assigned Xi Jinping to Zhaojiahe Village in Jiajianping Commune to lead social education efforts. Due to his effective work and strong rapport with the villagers, the community expressed a desire to keep him there. However, after Liangjiahe Village advocated for his return, Xi went back in July that same year. In 1999, he was promoted to the office of Vice Governor of Fujian, and became governor a year later. Xi proposed the concept of the [[Golden Triangle at Min River]] ({{lang-zh|闽江口金三角经济圈}}) and oversaw the construction of the Fuzhou 3820 Project Master Plan, which outlines Fuzhou City's growth strategy for 3, 8, and 20 years.{{cite book | author=《福州年鉴》编辑委员会 | title=福州年鉴 | publisher=中国统计出版社 | year=1995 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3YmzAAAAIAAJ | language=zh | access-date=2024-11-07 | page=16}} He concentrated on the development of [[Changle International Airport]], the [[Min River Water Transfer Project]], the [[Fuzhou Telecommunication Hub]], and [[Fuzhou Port]], among others. He concentrated on attracting Taiwanese and foreign investment,{{cite news|url=https://thediplomat.com/2014/11/from-fujian-chinas-xi-offers-economic-olive-branch-to-taiwan/|title=From Fujian, China's Xi Offers Economic Olive Branch to Taiwan|last=Tiezzi|first=Shannon|date=4 November 2014|newspaper=[[The Diplomat (magazine)|The Diplomat]]|language=en-US|url-access=limited|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610145941/https://thediplomat.com/2014/11/from-fujian-chinas-xi-offers-economic-olive-branch-to-taiwan/|archive-date=10 June 2016|access-date=17 March 2016}} establishing [[Southwest TPV Electronics]] and [[Southeast Automobile]] in Fuzhou, and fostering [[Fuyao Glass]], [[Newland Digital Technology]] and other manufacturing firms. Furthermore, he rehabilitated local cultural landmarks, including as the [[Sanfang Qixiang]] in Fuzhou, advanced urban renewal initiatives, and effectively addressed the issue of poverty alleviation on [[Pingtan Island]]. In 1995, Xi Jinping was elevated to deputy secretary of the [[Fujian Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party]] and served as [[Governor of Fujian]] from 1999 to 2002, during which he presented the notion of "[[Megalopolises in China|Megalopolises]]" and advocated for the inter-island growth strategy of Fuzhou and Xiamen, which motivated local officials to swiftly overcome the repercussions of the Yuanhua smuggling case ({{lang-zh|远华走私案}}) and adopt a new development strategy.{{cite book | title=驼铃: 大众文学| publisher=驼铃杂志社 | issue=172–177 | year=2000 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7No2AAAAIAAJ | language=zh | access-date=2024-11-07 | page=45}} Xi also oversaw the development of "Digital Fujian", including the province's complaint hotline into the "[[12345 hotline|12345 Citizen Service Platform]]," so enhancing organizational efficiency. {{cite book | last=Chan | first=A.L. | title=Xi Jinping: Political Career, Governance, and Leadership, 1953-2018 | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2022 | isbn=978-0-19-761522-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HH1ZEAAAQBAJ&pg=PA547 | access-date=2024-11-07 | page=547}} === Zhejiang === In 2002, Xi left Fujian and took up leading political positions in neighbouring Zhejiang. He eventually took over as [[Fujian Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|provincial Party Committee]] secretary after several months as acting governor, occupying a top provincial office for the first time in his career. In 2002, he was elected a full member of the [[16th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|16th Central Committee]], marking his ascension to the national stage. While in Zhejiang, Xi presided over reported growth rates averaging 14% per year.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1068825/chinas-leadership-transition-xi-jinpings-time-zhejiang|title=Xi Jinping's time in Zhejiang: doing the business|last=Ho|first=Louise|date=25 October 2012|newspaper=[[South China Morning Post]]|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160429160349/http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1068825/chinas-leadership-transition-xi-jinpings-time-zhejiang|archive-date=29 April 2016|access-date=9 December 2019}} During this period, Zhejiang increasingly transitioned away from heavy industry.{{Cite book |last=Chatwin |first=Jonathan |title=The Southern Tour: Deng Xiaoping and the Fight for China's Future |publisher=[[Bloomsbury Academic]] |year=2024 |isbn=9781350435711 |pages=}}{{Rp|page=121}} His career in Zhejiang was marked by a tough and straightforward stance against corrupt officials. This earned him a name in the national media and drew the attention of China's top leaders.{{cite news|url=http://opinion.dwnews.com/news/2014-12-25/59626005.html |script-title=zh:习近平为官之道 拎着乌纱帽干事|last1=Wang|first1=Lei|date=25 December 2014|work=[[Duowei News]]|access-date=7 September 2019|language=zh-hans|trans-title=Xi Jinping's Governmental Path – Carries Official Administrative Posts|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203225014/http://opinion.dwnews.com/news/2014-12-25/59626005.html|archive-date=3 February 2015}} Between 2004 and 2007, [[Li Qiang]] acted as Xi's chief of staff through his position as secretary-general of the [[Zhejiang Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|Zhejiang Party Committee]], where they developed close mutual ties.{{Cite news |last1=Tian |first1=Yew Lun |last2=Chen |first2=Laurie |last3=Cash |first3=Joe |date=11 March 2023 |title=Li Qiang, Xi confidant, takes reins as China's premier |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/china/li-qiang-xi-confidant-takes-reins-chinas-premier-2023-03-11/ |access-date=24 May 2023 |archive-date=24 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230524163326/https://www.reuters.com/world/china/li-qiang-xi-confidant-takes-reins-chinas-premier-2023-03-11/ |url-status=live}} === Shanghai === Following the dismissal of Shanghai [[Chinese Communist Party Shanghai Committee|Party secretary]] [[Chen Liangyu]] in September 2006 due to a [[Shanghai pension scandal|social security fund scandal]], Xi was transferred to Shanghai in March 2007, where he was the party secretary there for seven months.{{cite news|url=http://news.sohu.com/20070324/n248946143.shtml|script-title=zh:习近平任上海市委书记 韩正不再代理市委书记|date=24 March 2007|work=[[Sohu]]|access-date=7 September 2019|language=zh-Hans|trans-title=Xi Jinping is Secretary of Shanghai Municipal Party Committee – Han Zheng is No Longer Acting Party Secretary|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016061557/http://news.sohu.com/20070324/n248946143.shtml|archive-date=16 October 2007|url-status=live}}{{Cite news |date=15 November 2012 |title=China new leaders: Xi Jinping heads line-up for politburo |language=en-GB |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20322288 |url-status=live |access-date=25 August 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190909102154/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20322288 |archive-date=9 September 2019}} In Shanghai, Xi avoided controversy and was known for strictly observing party discipline. For example, Shanghai administrators attempted to earn favour with him by arranging a special train to shuttle him between Shanghai and [[Hangzhou]] for him to complete handing off his work to his successor as Zhejiang party secretary [[Zhao Hongzhu]]. However, Xi reportedly refused to take the train, citing a loosely enforced party regulation that stipulated that special trains can only be reserved for "national leaders."{{cite news|url=http://www.boxun.com/news/gb/china/2013/07/201307110449.shtml#.VTxXVvnF_tU|script-title=zh:从上海到北京 习近平贴身秘书只有钟绍军|date=11 July 2013|work=[[Mingjing News]]|access-date=12 September 2019|language=zh-hans|trans-title=From Shanghai to Beijing, Zhong Shaojun Has Been Xi Jinping's Only Personal Secretary|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612141343/http://www.boxun.com/news/gb/china/2013/07/201307110449.shtml#.VTxXVvnF_tU|archive-date=12 June 2018|url-status=live}} While in Shanghai, he worked on preserving unity of the local party organisation. He pledged there would be no 'purges' during his administration, despite the fact many local officials were thought to have been implicated in the Chen Liangyu corruption scandal.{{sfn|Lam|2015|p=56}} On most issues, Xi largely echoed the line of the central leadership.{{cite news|url=http://www.caijing.com.cn/2007-10-22/100034588.html |script-title=zh:新晋政治局常委: 习近平|date=22 October 2007|work=[[Caijing]]|access-date=12 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222175301/http://www.caijing.com.cn/2007-10-22/100034588.html|archive-date=22 December 2015|language=zh-hans|trans-title=Newly Appointed Member of Politburo Standing Committee: Xi Jinping}} ==Politburo Standing Committee== [[File:President George W. Bush with Vice President Xi Jinping.jpg|thumb|Xi Jinping greeting U.S. president [[George W. Bush]] in August 2008|left]] [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in China 28 September 2010-6.jpeg|thumb|Xi Jinping with Russian president [[Dmitry Medvedev]] on 28 September 2010|left]] Xi was appointed to the nine-man PSC at the [[17th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party|17th Party Congress]] in October 2007. He was ranked above [[Li Keqiang]], an indication that he was going to succeed Hu Jintao as China's [[Succession of power in China|next leader]]. In addition, Xi also held the [[First Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party|first secretary]] of the CCP's [[Secretariat of the Chinese Communist Party|Central Secretariat]]. This assessment was further supported at the [[11th National People's Congress]] in March 2008, when Xi was elected as vice president of the PRC.{{Cite news |date=16 March 2008 |title=Wen Jiabao re-elected China PM |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2008/3/16/wen-jiabao-re-elected-china-pm |access-date=13 August 2022 |website=[[Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera]] |language=en |archive-date=13 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220813171805/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2008/3/16/wen-jiabao-re-elected-china-pm |url-status=live}} Following his elevation, Xi held a broad range of portfolios. He was put in charge of the comprehensive preparations for the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in Beijing, as well as being the central government's leading figure in Hong Kong and Macau affairs. In addition, he also became the new president of the [[Central Party School of the Chinese Communist Party|Central Party School]] of the CCP, its cadre-training and ideological education wing. In the wake of the [[2008 Sichuan earthquake]], Xi visited disaster areas in [[Shaanxi]] and [[Gansu]]. He made his first foreign trip as vice president to North Korea, Mongolia, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Yemen from 17 to 25 June 2008.{{cite web |date=5 June 2008 |title=Vice-President Xi Jinping to Visit DPRK, Mongolia, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Yemen |url=http://www.mfa.gov.cn/eng/wjdt/wsrc/t462294.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723214209/http://www.mfa.gov.cn/eng/wjdt/wsrc/t462294.htm |archive-date=23 July 2011 |access-date=20 October 2010 |website=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (China)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] |publisher=}} After the Olympics, Xi was assigned the post of committee chair for the preparations of the [[60th Anniversary of the People's Republic of China|60th Anniversary Celebrations]] of the founding of the PRC. He was also reportedly at the helm of a top-level CCP committee dubbed the [[6521 Project]], which was charged with ensuring social stability during a series of politically sensitive anniversaries in 2009.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/10/world/asia/10china.html|title=China's Leaders See a Calendar Full of Anniversaries, and Trouble|last=Wines|first=Michael|date=9 March 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=8 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160721045913/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/10/world/asia/10china.html|archive-date=21 July 2016|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|url-access=limited}} Xi's position as the apparent successor to become the paramount leader was threatened with the rapid rise of [[Bo Xilai]], the party secretary of [[Chongqing]] at the time. Bo was expected to join the PSC at the [[18th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party|18th Party Congress]], with most expecting that he would try to eventually maneuver himself into replacing Xi.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/d67b90f0-d140-11e1-8957-00144feabdc0|archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221211221204/https://www.ft.com/content/d67b90f0-d140-11e1-8957-00144feabdc0|archive-date=11 December 2022|url-access=subscription|url-status=live|title=Bo Xilai: power, death and politics|last=Anderlini|first=Jamil|date=20 July 2012|work=[[Financial Times]]|access-date=11 January 2020}} Bo's policies in Chongqing inspired imitations throughout China and received praise from Xi himself during Xi's visit to Chongqing in 2010. Records of praises from Xi were later erased after he became paramount leader. Bo's downfall would come with the [[Wang Lijun incident]], which opened the door for Xi to come to power without challengers.{{Cite news|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/10/19/the-resistible-rise-of-xi-jinping/|title=The Resistible Rise of Xi Jinping|last=Palmer|first=James|date=19 October 2017|work=[[Foreign Policy (magazine)|Foreign Policy]]|access-date=11 January 2020|archive-date=6 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200206195505/https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/10/19/the-resistible-rise-of-xi-jinping/|url-status=live}} Xi is considered one of the most successful members of the Princelings, a quasi-clique of politicians who are descendants of early Chinese Communist revolutionaries. Former prime minister of Singapore, [[Lee Kuan Yew]], when asked about Xi, said he felt he was "a thoughtful man who has gone through many trials and tribulations."{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/xi-jinping-chinas-new-boss-and-l-word-95021|title=Xi Jinping: China's New Boss And The 'L' Word|last=Ansfield|first=Jonathan|date=22 December 2007|work=[[Newsweek]]|access-date=20 October 2010|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330064319/http://www.newsweek.com/id/81558|archive-date=30 March 2010}} Lee also commented: "I would put him in the [[Nelson Mandela]] class of persons. A person with enormous emotional stability who does not allow his personal misfortunes or sufferings affect his judgment. In other words, he is impressive."{{cite news|url=https://world.time.com/2007/11/19/chinas_nelson_mandela/|title=China's Nelson Mandela|last=Elegant|first=Simon|date=19 November 2007|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|access-date=8 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090728171010/http://china.blogs.time.com/2007/11/19/chinas_nelson_mandela/|archive-date=28 July In Iowa, he met with the family that previously hosted him during his 1985 tour as a [[Hebei]] provincial official.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/16/world/asia/xi-jinping-of-china-makes-a-return-trip-to-iowa.html|title=Xi Jinping of China Makes a Return Trip to Iowa|last=Johnson|first=Kirk|date=15 February 2012|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=12 September 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190621114147/https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/16/world/asia/xi-jinping-of-china-makes-a-return-trip-to-iowa.html|archive-date=21 June 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|url-access=limited}} ===Accession to top posts=== {{See also|Generations of Chinese leadership|Succession of power in China}} A few months before his ascendancy to the party leadership, Xi disappeared from official media coverage and cancelled meetings with foreign officials for several weeks beginning on 1 September 2012, causing rumors. He then reappeared on 15 September.{{Cite magazine |last=Beech |first=Hannah |date=15 September 2012 |title=China's Heir Apparent Xi Jinping Reappears in Public After a Two-Week Absence |url=https://world.time.com/2012/09/15/chinas-heir-apparent-xi-jinping-reappears-in-public-after-a-two-week-absence/ |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |language=en-US |issn=0040-781X |access-date=20 August 2022 |archive-date=14 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220814104509/https://world.time.com/2012/09/15/chinas-heir-apparent-xi-jinping-reappears-in-public-after-a-two-week-absence/ |url-status=live}} On 15 November 2012, Xi was elected to the posts of general secretary of the CCP and chairman of the CMC by the [[18th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|18th Central Committee of the CCP]]. This made him, informally, the [[paramount leader]] and the first to be born after the founding of the PRC. The following day Xi led the new line-up of the PSC onto the stage in their first public appearance.{{cite news |date=17 November 2012 |title=China Confirms Leadership Change |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-20322288 |access-date=15 November 2012 Keqiang retaining their seats; the other five members were new.{{Cite news |date=15 November 2012 |title=Xi Jinping: China's 'princeling' new leader |newspaper=[[Hindustan Times]] July 2014}} Xi mentioned the aspirations of the average person, remarking, "Our people ... expect better education, more stable jobs, better income, more reliable social security, medical care of a higher standard, more comfortable living conditions, and a more beautiful environment." Xi also vowed to tackle corruption at the highest levels, alluding that it would threaten the CCP's survival; he was reticent about far-reaching economic reforms.{{cite news |date=15 November 2012 |title=Full text: China's new party chief Xi Jinping's speech |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20338586 |url-status=live |access-date=7 September 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190914232334/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20338586 |archive-date=14 September 2019}} In December 2012, Xi visited [[Guangdong]] in his first trip outside Beijing since taking the Party leadership. The overarching theme of the trip was to call for further economic reform and a strengthened military. Xi visited the statue of Deng Xiaoping and his trip was described as following in the footsteps of [[Deng Xiaoping#Resignation and 1992 southern tour|Deng's own southern trip in 1992]], which provided the impetus for further economic reforms in China after conservative party leaders stalled many of Deng's reforms in the aftermath of the [[1989 Tiananmen Square protests and massacre]]. On his trip, Xi consistently alluded to his signature slogan, the "Chinese Dream." "This dream can be said to be the dream of a strong nation. And for the military, it is a dream of a strong military," Xi told sailors.{{cite news |last=Page |first=Jeremy |date=13 March 2013 |title=New Beijing Leader's 'China Dream' |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324128504578348774040546346 |url-status=live |access-date=8 September 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191011195356/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324128504578348774040546346 |archive-date=11 October 2019}} Xi's trip was significant in that he departed from the established convention of Chinese leaders' travel routines in multiple ways. Rather than dining out, Xi and his entourage ate regular hotel buffet. He travelled in a large van with his colleagues rather than a fleet of limousines, and did not restrict traffic on the parts of the highway he travelled.{{cite news |last1=Chen |first1=Zhuang |date=10 December 2012 |title=The symbolism of Xi Jinping's trip south |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20662947 |url-status=live |access-date=22 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140708094339/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20662947 |archive-date=8 July 2014}} Xi was elected president on 14 March 2013, in a confirmation vote by the [[12th National People's Congress]] in Beijing. He received 2,952 for, one vote against, and three abstentions. He replaced Hu Jintao, who retired after serving two terms.{{cite news |last=Demick |first=Barbara |author-link=Barbara Demick |date=3 March 2013 |title=China's Xi Jinping formally assumes title of president |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-china-xi-presidency-20130313,0,1240600.story |url-status=live |access-date=16 March 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130316021753/http://www.latimes.com/news/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-china-xi-presidency-20130313,0,1240600.story |archive-date=16 March 2013}} On 17 March, Xi and his new ministers arranged a meeting with the [[Leung Chun-ying as Chief Executive of Hong Kong|chief executive of Hong Kong]], [[CY Leung]], confirming his support for Leung.{{cite news |last1=Cheung |first1=Tony |last2=Ho |first2=Jolie |date=17 March 2013 |title=CY Leung to meet Xi Jinping in Beijing and explain cross-border policies |work=[[South China Morning Post]] |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1192587/cy-leung-meet-xi-jinping-beijing-and-explain-cross-border-policies |url-status=live |access-date=16 March 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318073700/http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1192587/cy-leung-meet-xi-jinping-beijing-and-explain-cross-border-policies |archive-date=18 March 2013}} Within hours of his election, Xi discussed [[cyber security]] and North Korea with U.S. President Barack Obama over the phone. Obama announced the visits of treasury and state secretaries [[Jack Lew]] and [[John F. Kerry]] to China the following week.{{cite news |date=15 March 2013 |title=China names Xi Jinping as new president |website=Inquirer.net |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/373967/china-names-xi-jinping-as-new-president |url-status=live |access-date=16 March 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130317020402/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/373967/china-names-xi-jinping-as-new-president |archive-date=17 March 2013}} ==Leadership== {{Main|China under Xi Jinping}} ===Anti-corruption campaign=== {{main|Anti-corruption campaign under Xi Jinping}} {{Quote box | quote = "To speak the truth" means to focus on the nature of things, to speak frankly, and follow the truth. Moreover, he highlighted that the premise of telling the truth is to listen to the truth. | source = — Xi Jinping during a speech in 2012{{cite book | title=Narrating China's Governance | chapter=Stories of Incorrupt Government: "The Corruption and Unjustness of Officials Give Birth to the Decline of Governance" | publisher=Springer Singapore | publication-place=Singapore | date=20 Nov 2019 | isbn=978-981-329-177-5 | doi=10.1007/978-981-32-9178-2_1 | pages=3–39 | last1=People's Daily | first1=Department of Commentary}} | align = right | width = 25em }} Xi vowed to crack down on corruption immediately after he ascended to power. In his inaugural speech as general secretary, Xi mentioned that fighting corruption was one of the toughest challenges for the party.{{cite news |date=15 November 2012 |title=Xi Jinping's inaugural Speech |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20338586 |url-status=live |access-date=7 September 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190914232334/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20338586 |archive-date=14 September 2019}} A few months into his term, Xi outlined the [[Eight-point Regulation]], listing rules intended to curb corruption and waste during official party business; it aimed at stricter discipline on the conduct of officials. Xi vowed to root out "tigers and flies," that is, high-ranking officials and ordinary party functionaries.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/28/world/asia/xi-jinping-imposes-austerity-measures-on-chinas-elite.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|title=Elite in China Face Austerity Under Xi's Rule|last=Jacobs|first=Andrew|date=27 March 2013|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=7 September 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181130054920/https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/28/world/asia/xi-jinping-imposes-austerity-measures-on-chinas-elite.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|archive-date=30 November 2018|author-link=Andrew Jacobs (journalist)}} Xi initiated cases against former CMC vice-chairmen [[Xu Caihou]] and [[Guo Boxiong]], former PSC member and security chief [[Zhou Yongkang]] and former Hu Jintao chief aide [[Ling Jihua]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-03-03/china-s-xi-broadens-graft-crackdown-to-boost-influence.html|title=President Xi's Anti-Corruption Campaign Biggest Since Mao|last=Oster|first=Shai|date=4 March 2014|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|access-date=7 September 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209164917/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-03-03/china-s-xi-broadens-graft-crackdown-to-boost-influence.html|archive-date=9 December 2014|author-link=Shai Oster}} Along with new disciplinary chief [[Wang Qishan]], Xi's [[Xi–Li Administration|administration]] spearheaded the formation of "centrally-dispatched inspection teams". These were cross-jurisdictional squads whose task was to gain understanding of the operations of provincial and local party organizations, and enforce party discipline mandated by Beijing. Work teams had the effect of identifying and initiating investigations of high-ranking officials. Over one hundred provincial-ministerial level officials were implicated during a nationwide anti-corruption campaign. These included former and current regional officials, leading figures of state-owned enterprises and central government organs, and generals. Within the first two years of the campaign alone, over 200,000 officials received warnings, fines, and demotions.{{sfn|Heilmann|2017|pp=62–75}} The campaign has led to the downfall of prominent news|url=http://www.jamestown.org/programs/chinabrief/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=43160&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=25&cHash=d5d24d2f82c5981963c0180d300e62cd#.VOOBN_nF9uM|title=China's Soft-Power Beginning in 2013, the CCP under Xi has created a series of Central Leading Groups: supra-ministerial steering committees, designed to bypass existing institutions when making decisions, and ostensibly make policy-making a more efficient process. Xi was also believed to have diluted the authority of premier Li Keqiang, taking authority over the economy which has generally been considered to be the domain of the premier.{{Cite news |date=28 September 2020 |title=Li Keqiang: China's marginalised premier |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-19870221 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221017104619/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-19870221 |archive-date=17 October 2022 |access-date=17 October 2022 |work=[[BBC News]] |language=en-GB}}{{Cite news |last=Wei |first=Lingling |date=11 May 2022 |title=China's Forgotten Premier Steps Out of Xi's Shadow as Economic Fixer |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-premier-li-keqiang-xi-jinping-11652277107 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230531130648/https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-premier-li-keqiang-xi-jinping-11652277107 |archive-date=31 May 2023 |access-date=17 October 2022 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |language=en-US |issn=0099-9660}} February 2014 oversaw the creation of the [[Central Cyberspace Affairs Commission|Central Leading Group for Cybersecurity and Informatization]] with Xi as its leader. The State Internet Information Office (SIIO), previously under the [[State Council Information Office]] (SCI), was transferred to the central leading group and renamed in English into the Cyberspace Administration of China.{{Cite web |last1=Attrill |first1=Nathan |last2=Fritz |first2=Audrey |date=24 November 2021 |title=China's cyber vision: How the Cyberspace Administration of China is building a new consensus on global internet governance |url=https://ad-aspi.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/2021-11/Chinas%20cyber%20vision.pdf?VersionId=M0ePH4Ij3w7WRJrLlhyxVvt269MWSYOs |access-date=29 December 2022 |website=[[Australian Strategic Policy Institute]] |archive-date=29 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221229145556/https://ad-aspi.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/2021-11/Chinas%20cyber%20vision.pdf?VersionId=M0ePH4Ij3w7WRJrLlhyxVvt269MWSYOs |url-status=live}} As part of managing the financial system, the [[Financial Stability and Development Committee]], a State Council body, was established in 2017. Chaired by vice premier [[Liu He (politician)|Liu He]] during its existence, the committee was disestablished by the newly established Central Financial Commission during the 2023 Party and state reforms.{{Cite news |last1=Chen |first1=Laurie |last2=Tang |first2=Ziyi |date=16 March 2023 |title=China to create powerful financial watchdog run by Communist Party |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/china/china-create-powerful-financial-watchdog-run-by-communist-party-2023-03-16/ |access-date=17 March 2023 |archive-date=16 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230316162813/https://www.reuters.com/world/china/china-create-powerful-financial-watchdog-run-by-communist-party-2023-03-16/ |url-status=live}} Xi has increased the role of the [[Central Financial and Economic Affairs Commission]] at the expense of the [[State Council of the People's Republic of China|State Council]].{{Cite news |last=Mitchell |first=Tom |date=25 July 2016 |title=Xi's China: The rise of party politics |url=https://www.ft.com/content/57371736-4b69-11e6-88c5-db83e98a590a |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221211221251/https://www.ft.com/content/57371736-4b69-11e6-88c5-db83e98a590a |archive-date=11 December 2022 |access-date=31 January 2020 |work=[[Financial Times]]}} 2018 has seen larger reforms to the bureaucracy. In 2020, all elections at all levels of the [[System of people's congress|people's congress system]] and NPC were mandated to adhere to the leadership of the CCP.{{Cite journal |last1=Hao |first1=Mingsong |last2=Ke |first2=Xiwang |date=5 July 2023 |title=Personal Networks and Grassroots Election Participation in China: Findings from the Chinese General Social Survey |journal=[[Journal of Chinese Political Science]] |language=en |volume=29 |issue=1 |pages=159–184 |doi=10.1007/s11366-023-09861-3 |issn=1080-6954 |doi-access=free}} 2023 has seen further reforms to the CCP and state bureaucracy, most notably the strengthening of Party control over the financial and technology domains.{{Cite news |last1=Wong |first1=Chun Han |last2=Zhai |first2=Keith |date=16 March 2023 |title=China's Communist Party Overhaul Deepens Control Over Finance, Technology |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-communist-party-overhaul-deepens-control-over-finance-technology-6acdd43c?mod=world_lead_pos5 |access-date=16 March 2023 |archive-date=16 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230316221649/https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-communist-party-overhaul-deepens-control-over-finance-technology-6acdd43c?mod=world_lead_pos5 |url-status=live}} This included the creation of two CCP bodies for overseeing finance; the [[Central Financial Commission]] (CFC), as well as the revival of the [[Central Financial Work Commission]] (CFWC) that was previously dissolved in 2002. The party aimed to reform the legal system, which had been perceived as ineffective at delivering justice and affected by corruption, local government interference and lack of constitutional oversight. If accomplished, this would lower the expected rise in global temperature by 0.2–0.3 °C – "the biggest single reduction ever estimated by the Climate Action Tracker."{{cite web |date=23 September 2020 |title=China going carbon neutral before 2060 would lower warming projections by around 0.2 to 0.3 degrees C |url=https://climateactiontracker.org/press/china-carbon-neutral-before-2060-would-lower-warming-projections-by-around-2-to-3-tenths-of-a-degree/ |access-date=27 September 2020 |website=[[Climate Action Tracker]]}} Xi mentioned the link between the COVID-19 pandemic and nature destruction as one of the reasons for the decision, saying that "Humankind can no longer afford to ignore the repeated warnings of nature."{{cite news |date=23 September 2020 |title=China, the world's top global emitter, aims to go carbon-neutral by 2060 |work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-09-23/china-world-top-global-emitter-aims-carbon-neutral-by-2060/12691974 |access-date=29 September 2020}} On 27 September, Chinese scientists presented a detailed plan how to achieve the target.{{cite news |date=29 September 2020 |title=China's top climate scientists unveil road map to 2060 goal |newspaper=[[The Japan Times]] |agency=[[Bloomberg News]] |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/09/29/asia-pacific/science-health-asia-pacific/china-climate-change-road-map-2060/ |access-date=29 September 2020}} In September 2021, Xi announced that China will not build "coal-fired power projects abroad, which was said to be potentially "pivotal" in reducing emissions. The Belt and Road Initiative did not include financing such projects already in the first half of 2021.{{cite news |last1=Brant |first1=Robin |date=22 September 2021 |title=China pledges to stop building new coal energy plants abroad |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-58647481 |access-date=29 September 2021}} Xi has popularized a metaphor of "two mountains" to emphasize the importance of environmental protection.{{Cite book |last=Li |first=David Daokui |title=China's World View: Demystifying China to Prevent Global Conflict |date=2024 |publisher=[[W. W. Norton & Company]] |isbn=978-0393292398 |location=New York, NY |author-link=David Daokui Li}}{{Rp|page=164}} The concept is that a mountain made of gold or silver is valuable, but [[Clear waters and green mountains|green mountains with clear waters are more valuable]].{{Rp|page=164}} The slogan's meaning is that economic development priorities must also provide for economic protection.{{Rp|page=164}} Xi Jinping did not attend [[2021 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP26]] personally. Xi has also never given a press conference since becoming paramount leader, except in rare joint press conferences with foreign leaders.{{Cite web |last=McGregor |first=Richard |date=21 August 2022 |title=Xi Jinping's Radical Secrecy |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2022/08/china-xi-jinping-biography-opacity/671195/ |access-date=21 August 2022 |website=[[The Atlantic]] |language=en}} ''The Wall Street Journal'' reported that Xi prefers micromanaging in governance, in contrast to previous leaders such as Hu Jintao who left details of major policies to lower-ranking officials. What the public opposes and hates, we must address and resolve.{{pb}} [M]aterial and cultural needs grown; demands for democracy, rule of law, fairness and justice, security, and a better environment are also increasing each day. | source = — Xi Jinping during a speech in 2017{{cite web | last=Ide | first=Bill | title=Xi Lays Out New Vision for Communist China | website=Voice of America | date=18 Oct 2017 | url=https://www.voanews.com/amp/xi-jinping-opens-national-congress/4075475.html | access-date=30 Jul 2024}} | align = right | width = 25em }} ===Chinese Dream=== {{main|Chinese Dream}} [[File:Lujiazui 2016.jpg|thumb|According to ''[[Qiushi]]'', the Chinese Dream is about Chinese prosperity, collective effort, socialism, and national glory.]] Xi and CCP ideologues coined the phrase "Chinese Dream" to describe his overarching plans for China as its leader. Xi first used the phrase during a high-profile visit to the [[National Museum of China]] on 29 November 2012, where he and his [[Politburo Standing Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|Standing Committee]] colleagues were attending a "national revival" exhibition. Since then, the phrase has become the signature political slogan of the Xi era.{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/leaders/2013/05/04/xi-jinping-and-the-chinese-dream|title=Xi Jinping and the Chinese dream|date=4 May 2013|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|access-date=12 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510092423/http://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21577070-vision-chinas-new-president-should-serve-his-people-not-nationalist-state-xi-jinping|archive-date=10 May 2016|issn=0013-0613}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/9935609/Xi-Jinping-calls-for-a-Chinese-Dream.html|title=Xi Jinping calls for a Chinese dream|last1=Moore|first1=Malcolm|date=17 March 2013|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|access-date=20 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130320072154/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/9935609/Xi-Jinping-calls-for-a-Chinese-Dream.html|archive-date=20 March 2013|url-status=live}} The origin of the term "Chinese Dream" is unclear. While the phrase has been used before by journalists and scholars,{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/china/archive/2013/05/todays-china-notes-dreams-obstacles/275544/|title=Today's China Notes: Dreams, Obstacles|last=Fallows|first=James|date=3 May 2013|work=[[The Atlantic]]|access-date=7 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180712023142/https://www.theatlantic.com/china/archive/2013/05/todays-china-notes-dreams-obstacles/275544/|archive-date=12 July 2018|url-status=live}} some publications have posited the term likely drew its inspiration from the concept of the [[American Dream]].{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/analects/2013/05/chinese-dream-0|title=The role of Thomas Friedman|last=M.|first=J.|date=6 May 2013|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|access-date=12 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028145059/https://www.economist.com/blogs/analects/2013/05/chinese-dream-0|archive-date=28 October 2017|url-status=live}} ''The Economist'' noted the abstract and seemingly accessible nature of the concept with no specific overarching policy stipulations may be a deliberate departure from the jargon-heavy ideologies of his predecessors.{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21577063-chinas-new-leader-has-been-quick-consolidate-his-power-what-does-he-now-want-his|title=Chasing the Chinese dream |date=4 May 2013|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|access-date=12 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028080732/http://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21577063-chinas-new-leader-has-been-quick-consolidate-his-power-what-does-he-now-want-his|archive-date=28 October 2016|issn=0013-0613}} Xi has linked the "Chinese Dream" with the phrase "great rejuvenation of the [[Zhonghua minzu|Chinese nation]]."{{Cite web |last=Tao |first=Xie |date=14 March 2014 |title=Opinion: Is the Chinese dream fantasy or reality? |url=https://www.cnn.com/2014/03/14/world/asia/chinese-dream-anniversary-xi-jinping-president/index.html |access-date=14 August 2022 |website=[[CNN]]}}{{efn|{{zh|links=no|s=中华民族伟大复兴}}, which can also be translated as the "Great Renaissance of the Chinese nation" or the "Great revival of the Chinese people".}} ===Culture=== {{See also|Xi Jinping Thought on Culture}} In recent years, top political leaders of the CCP such as Xi have overseen the rehabilitation of ancient Chinese philosophical figures like [[Han Fei]] into the mainstream of Chinese thought alongside [[Confucianism]]. At a meeting with other officials in 2013, he quoted [[Confucius]], saying "he who rules by virtue is like the Pole Star, it maintains its place, and the multitude of stars pay homage." While visiting [[Shandong]], the birthplace of Confucius, in November, he told scholars that the Western world was "suffering a crisis of confidence" and that the CCP has been "the loyal inheritor and promoter of China's outstanding [[Traditional Chinese culture|traditional culture]]."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/12/world/leader-taps-into-chinese-classics-in-seeking-to-cement-power.html|title=Leader Taps into Chinese Classics in Seeking to Cement Power|last=Buckley|first=Chris|date=12 October 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190912091736/https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/12/world/leader-taps-into-chinese-classics-in-seeking-to-cement-power.html|archive-date=12 September 2019|access-date=7 September 2019}} According to several analysts, Xi's leadership has been characterised by a resurgence of the ancient political philosophy [[Legalism (Chinese philosophy)|Legalism]].{{cite journal |last1=Schneider |first1=David K. |title=China's New Legalism |journal=The National Interest |date=2016 |issue=143 |pages=19–25 |doi= |jstor=26557304}}{{cite web |last1=Crane |first1=Sam |title=Why Xi Jinping's China is Legalist, Not Confucian |url=https://chinachannel.org/2018/06/29/legalism/ |website=China Channel |date=29 June 2018 |access-date=24 November 2020 |archive-date=7 November 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201107225951/https://chinachannel.org/2018/06/29/legalism/ |url-status=dead}} Han Fei gained new prominence with favourable citations; one sentence of Han Fei's that Xi quoted appeared thousands of times in official Chinese media at the local, provincial, and national levels.{{cite news|url=https://thediplomat.com/2015/01/is-chinas-machiavelli-now-its-most-important-political-philosopher/|title=Is 'China's Machiavelli' Now Its Most Important Political Philosopher?|last=Mitchell|first=Ryan Mi|date=16 January 2015|newspaper=[[The Diplomat (magazine)|The Diplomat]]|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190912091739/https://thediplomat.com/2015/01/is-chinas-machiavelli-now-its-most-important-political-philosopher/|archive-date=12 September 2019|access-date=7 September 2019}} Xi has additionally supported the [[Neo-Confucianism|Neo-Confucian]] philosopher [[Wang Yangming]], telling local leaders to promote him.{{Cite news |last=Johnson |first=Ian |date=18 October 2017 |title=Forget Marx and Mao. Chinese City Honors Once-Banned Confucian. |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/18/world/asia/china-guiyang-wang-yangming-confucian.html |access-date=13 August 2022 |issn=0362-4331}} On 15 October 2014, Xi Jinping emulated the [[Yan'an Talks]] with his 'Speech at the Forum on Literature and Art.'{{Cite book |last=Sorace |first=Christian |title=Afterlives of Chinese Communism: Political Concepts from Mao to Xi |date=2019 |publisher=[[Australian National University Press]] |isbn=9781760462499 |location=Acton, Australia |chapter=Aesthetics}}{{Rp|page=15}} Consistent with Mao's view in the Yan'an Talks, Xi believes works of art should be judged by political criteria.{{Rp|page=16}} In 2021, Xi quoted the Yan'an Talks during the opening ceremony of the 11th National Congress of the [[China Federation of Literary and Art Circles]] and the 10th National Congress of the [[China Writers Association|Chinese Writers Association]].{{Rp|page=174}} According to Xi, art should be judged by political criteria.{{Rp|page=16}} This view rejects the concept of art-for-art's-sake and contends that art should serve the goal of national rejuvenation.{{Rp|page=16}} Xi criticizes market-driven art which he deems sensationalist, particularly works which "exaggerate society's dark side" for profit.{{Rp|page=16}} He ordered the arts industry to "tell China's stories and spread Chinese voices to strengthen the country's international communication capacity."{{cite web |author1=Joyce Cheng |author2=Bang Xiao |date=2022-07-31 |title=Globally acclaimed author Yan Geling considering giving up writing in native Chinese over censorship |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-07-31/author-yan-geling-criticises-beijing-censorship/101276516 |work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]}} Xi has also overseen a revival of traditional Chinese culture, breaking from the CCP's previous path, which had often attacked it.{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/china/2017/08/17/the-communist-party-is-redefining-what-it-means-to-be-chinese|title=The Communist Party is redefining what it means to be Chinese|date=17 August 2017|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|access-date=23 January 2020}} He has called traditional culture the "soul" of the nation and the "foundation" of the CCP's culture.{{Cite news |last=Zi |first=Yang |date=6 July 2016 |title=Xi Jinping and China's Traditionalist Restoration |work=[[The Jamestown Foundation]] |publisher= |url=https://jamestown.org/program/xi-jinping-chinas-traditionalist-restoration/ |access-date=23 January 2020}} Xi has also called for integrating the basic tenets of Marxism with China's traditional culture. [[Hanfu]], the traditional dress of Han Chinese, has seen a revival under him, associated with the revival of traditional culture.{{Cite news|url=https://www.afr.com/life-and-luxury/fashion-and-style/why-its-hip-to-be-oldfashioned-in-china-20181129-h18hql|title=China's 'Hanfu' movement is making it hip to be old-fashioned. Here's why.|last=Buckley|first=Chris|date=30 November 2018|work=[[The Australian Financial Review]]|access-date=23 January 2020}} He has established the "[[Confidence doctrine|four matters of confidence]]," which has later been added to the CCP constitution, calling for CCP members, government officials and the Chinese people to be "confident in our chosen path, confident in our guiding theories, confident in our political system, and confident in our culture." He has unveiled Global Civilisation initiative in 2023, calling for "respecting the diversity of civilisations, advocating the common values of humanity, valuing the inheritance and innovation of civilisations, and strengthening international people-to-people exchanges and cooperation" ===Ideology=== {{See also|Eight-point Regulation}} Xi has said that "only socialism can save China."{{Cite news |last=Tian |first=Yew Lun |date=9 September 2021 |title=Analysis: Unleashing reforms, Xi returns to China's socialist roots |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/china/unleashing-reforms-xi-returns-chinas-socialist-roots-2021-09-09/ |access-date=17 September 2022}} Xi has also declared [[socialism with Chinese characteristics]] to be the "only correct path to realize national rejuvenation."{{Cite web |date=9 October 2021 |title=Socialism with Chinese characteristics only correct path toward national rejuvenation: Xi |url=http://ex.chinadaily.com.cn/exchange/partners/82/rss/channel/www/columns/np4922/stories/WS61610570a310cdd39bc6dcc1.html |access-date=17 September 2022 |website=[[China Daily]]}} According to [[BBC News]], while the CCP was perceived to have abandoned its communist ideology since it initiated [[Chinese economic reform|economic reforms]] in the 1970s, Xi is believed by some observers to be more believing in the "idea of a communist project,"{{Cite news |last=McDonell |first=Stephen |date=22 September 2021 |title=Changing China: Xi Jinping's effort to return to socialism |language=en-GB |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-58579831 |access-date=17 September 2022}} being described as a [[Marxist–Leninist]] by former Australian prime minister Kevin Rudd.{{Cite news |last=Rudd |first=Kevin |author-link=Kevin Rudd |date=10 October 2022 |title=The World According to Xi Jinping |language=en-US |work=[[Foreign Affairs]] |url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/china/world-according-xi-jinping-china-ideologue-kevin-rudd |access-date=12 October 2022}} Xi's emphasis on prioritizing ideology has included re-asserting the Party's goal of eventually [[Communist mode of production|realizing communism]] and reprimanding those who dismiss communism as impractical or irrelevant.{{sfn|Pieke|Hofman|2022|p=48}} Xi described the communist ideal as the "calcium" in a Party member's spine, without which the Party member would suffer the "osteoporosis" of political decay and be unable to stand upright.{{sfn|Pieke|Hofman|2022|p=48}} Subscribing to the view that socialism will eventually triumph over capitalism, Xi has said "Marx and Engels's [[Dialectical materialism|analysis of the basic contradictions]] of [[Capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)|capitalist society]] is not outdated, nor is the [[historical materialism|historical materialist view]] that capitalism is bound to die out and socialism bound to win."{{Cite web |last=Hancock |first=Tom |date=6 June 2022 |title=Marxism Makes a Comeback in China's Crackdown on 'Disorderly Capital' |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2022-06-06/marxism-makes-a-comeback-in-china-s-crackdown-on-disorderly-capital |access-date=17 September 2022 |website=[[Bloomberg News]]}} Xi has overseen the increase of "Socialist Political Economy With Chinese Characteristics" as a major study topic for academics in China, aiming to decrease the influence of Western-influenced economics. Though he has called a stop to what he considers to be "disorderly expansion of capital," he has also said that "it is necessary to stimulate the vitality of capital of all types, including nonpublic capital, and give full play to its positive role." {{Quote box | quote = China's success proves that socialism is not dead. His Politburo Standing Committee colleagues, in their own reviews of Xi's keynote address at the Congress, prepended the name "Xi Jinping" in front of "Thought."{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/19/c_136689808.htm|title=CPC creates Xi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era|last1=Zhang|first1=Ling|date=18 October 2017|work=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|access-date=19 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171018195301/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/19/c_136689808.htm|archive-date=18 October 2017|url-status=dead}} On 24 October 2017, at its closing session, the 19th Party Congress approved the incorporation of Xi Jinping Thought into the Constitution of the CCP, while in March 2018, the National People's Congress changed the state constitution to include Xi Jinping Thought.{{Cite web |last=Ken |first=Suzuki |date=27 November 2018 |title=China's New "Xi Jinping Constitution": The Road to Totalitarianism |url=https://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/a05803/ |access-date=11 August 2022 |website=nippon.com |language=en}} [[File:201901 Xi Jinping's books at Shanghai Library.jpg|left|thumb|''[[The Governance of China]]'' in different languages presented at [[Shanghai Library]]]] Xi himself has described the Thought as part of the broad framework created around socialism with Chinese characteristics, a term coined by Deng Xiaoping that places China in the [[primary stage of socialism]]. In official party documentation and pronouncements by Xi's colleagues, the Thought is said to be a continuation of [[Marxism–Leninism]], [[Mao Zedong Thought]], Deng Xiaoping Theory, the Three Represents, and the [[Scientific Outlook on Development]], as part of a series of guiding ideologies that embody "Marxism adopted to Chinese conditions" and contemporary considerations. It has additionally been described as the "21st century Marxism" by two professors in the Central Party School of the CCP. Wang Huning, a top political adviser and a close ally of Xi, has been described as pivotal to developing Xi Jinping Thought. The concepts and context behind Xi Jinping Thought are elaborated in Xi's ''[[The Governance of China]]'' book series, published by the [[Foreign Languages Press]] for an international audience. Volume one was published in September 2014, followed by volume two in November 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-11/07/c_136733705.htm|title=Second volume of Xi's book on governance published|last=Yang|first=Yi|date=7 November 2017|publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206143920/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-11/07/c_136733705.htm|archive-date=6 December 2017|access-date=6 December 2017}} ''[[Xuexi Qiangguo]]'', an app for teaching Xi Jinping Thought had become the most popular smartphone app in China in 2019, as the CCP launched a new campaign that calls on its cadres to immerse themselves in the political doctrine every day.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/tech/apps-social/article/2186037/chinas-most-popular-app-propaganda-tool-teaching-xi-jinping-thought|title=China's most popular app is a propaganda tool teaching Xi Jinping Thought|last=Huang|first=Zheping|date=14 February 2019|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=7 September 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190920105809/https://www.scmp.com/tech/apps-social/article/2186037/chinas-most-popular-app-propaganda-tool-teaching-xi-jinping-thought|archive-date=20 September 2019}} ==Personal life== ===Family=== [[File:Peng Liyuan, Xi Jinping and Barack Obama in the Lincoln Bedroom.jpg|thumb|Xi Jinping, [[Peng Liyuan]] and U.S. president [[Barack Obama]] in the Lincoln Bedroom]] Xi's first marriage was to [[Ke Lingling]], the daughter of [[Ke Hua]], China's ambassador to the United Kingdom in the early 1980s. They divorced within a few years.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/11/07/world/asia/china-xi-jinping-profile/index.html|title=Xi Jinping: From 'sent-down youth' to China's top|last=Yuan|first=Elizabeth|date=8 November 2012|publisher=[[CNN]]|access-date=8 November 2012|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108195546/http://edition.cnn.com/2012/11/07/world/asia/china-xi-jinping-profile/index.html|archive-date=8 November 2012}} The two were said to fight "almost every day," and after the divorce, Ke moved to England. In 1987, Xi married the prominent Chinese folk singer Peng Liyuan.{{Cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2007-oct-23-fg-chileaders23-story.html|title=China's 'fifth generation' of leaders reflects nation's shifts|last=Magnier|first=Mark|date=23 October 2007|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|access-date=21 December 2009|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823133224/http://articles.latimes.com/2007/oct/23/world/fg-chileaders23|archive-date=23 August 2011}} Xi and Peng were introduced by friends as many Chinese couples were in the 1980s. Xi was reputedly academic during their courtship, inquiring about singing techniques.{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2012/02/13/peng-liyuan-meet-chinas-folk-song-singing-first-lady-in-waiting/|title=Meet China's Folk Star First Lady-in-Waiting|last=Page|first=Jeremy|date=12 February 2012|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|access-date=7 November 2012|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511045002/http://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2012/02/13/peng-liyuan-meet-chinas-folk-song-singing-first-lady-in-waiting/|archive-date=11 May 2012}} Peng Liyuan, a [[Celebrity|household name]] in China, was better known to the public than Xi until his political elevation. The couple frequently lived apart due largely to their separate professional lives. Peng has played a much more visible role as China's "first lady" compared to her predecessors; for example, Peng hosted U.S. First Lady [[Michelle Obama]] on her high-profile visit to China in March 2014.{{cite news|url=https://time.com/33164/michelle-obama-china-beijing-peng-liyuan/|title=Michelle Obama Tours Beijing With China's First Lady|last1=Beech|first1=Hannah|date=21 March 2014|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|access-date=17 July 2014|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626122108/http://time.com/33164/michelle-obama-china-beijing-peng-liyuan/|archive-date=26 June 2014}} Xi and Peng have a daughter named [[Xi Mingze]], who graduated from [[Harvard University]] in the spring of 2015. In 2011, Xi outlined a vision to turn China from a footballing minnow to a soccer superpower. He outlined a three-stage plan for the national team: to qualify for another [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]], to host a World Cup and to win a World Cup.{{cite web |author1=Andrew McNicol |author2=Andrew Raine |date=2023-04-07 |title=Xi Jinping wanted China to be a global soccer power. What went wrong? |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2023/04/07/china/xi-jinping-china-football-dream-fail-intl-hnk-dst/index.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.today/20240712102342/https://edition.cnn.com/2023/04/07/china/xi-jinping-china-football-dream-fail-intl-hnk-dst/index.html |archive-date=2024-07-12 |work=[[CNN]]}} In 2015, Xi approved China's 50-point plan for the sport, which included including soccer in the national school curriculum and setting up 50,000 soccer schools in the country by 2025.{{cite web|author=Tariq Panja|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/29/sports/soccer/china-soccer.html|title=China's Soccer Experiment Was a Flop. Now It May Be Over.|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2023-03-29}} However, according to [[CNN]], poor financial decisions and alleged high-level corruption coupled with a [[COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China|three-year pandemic]] have left the sport in tatters. In 2023, Xi said he is "not so sure" of the abilities of the national team.{{cite web |date=2023-11-19 |title=Xi says 'not so sure' of Chinese football team's abilities |url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/asia/china-xi-not-so-sure-football-team-abilities-world-cup-3931906 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231214013447/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/asia/china-xi-not-so-sure-football-team-abilities-world-cup-3931906 |archive-date=2023-12-14 |work=[[CNA (TV network)|Channel NewsAsia]]}} === Interests === Unlike previous Chinese leaders, Chinese state media has given a more encompassing view of Xi's private life, although still strictly controlled. According to Xinhua News Agency, Xi would swim one kilometer and walk every day as long as there was time, and is interested in foreign writers, especially Russian. Some of his favorite foreign authors include [[Leo Tolstoy]], [[Mikhail Sholokhov]],{{Cite web |title=A look at what's on Chinese President Xi Jinping's shelves |url=https://www.usfq.edu.ec/sites/default/files/inline-files/a-look-at-whats-on-chinese-president-xi-jinpings-shelves.pdf |website=[[Universidad San Francisco de Quito]] |quote=Xi Jinping talks about Western literature [...] "Dostoevsky is the deepest Russian writer, while Tolstoy is the widest. Xi reportedly invoked ''[[What Is to Be Done?
